p.s: John Worne thinks that language learning is vital for the UK's future prosperity and global standing.
The counterarguments is that since English is already the worldlanguageworld language there'dthere's no necessity in learning foreign languages.
Both statements show the truth.
Many countries in the world have English as an official language or at the very least actively teach it in schools.
A country that's often looked up upon here is India in that it fulfills both as an emerging market making it relatively easy for pure EnglishspeakersEnglish speakers to build ties.
But there are still plenty of places that don't have English as an official language.
And among those places one can also find schoolsystemsschool systems that don't put enough emphasis on teaching English.
Either due to conservatism or due to a lack of proper funding.
Such places get much harder to access if someone is purely reliant on a translator.
Not only hinders this working efficiently, it also fails at integrating it'sits system into a different culture.
In our globalized world companies like to outsource workplaces and even workforce.
This means that modern business ties go beyond simple cooperative agreements.
They range to a cultural extendextent in which both sides have to communicate on the same wavelength and understand each other.
This is a somthingsomething no translator in the world can achieve.
If an English teacher from the UK is said to work in Japan for instance, he'll face a totally different enviromentenvironment with a totally different society.
Communication between him and the natives makes adapting to the norms a neccesitynecessity.
And the biggest single thing he can do is learning the language.
So I agree that language learning is essential for prosperity in a globalized world.
A native EnglishspeakerEnglish speaker with a translator cannot achieve the same level of effective communication and adaption as someone who can understand a foreign language.
It reinforces ties and helps to succesfully leap into new markets.
